title: The Most Common Property Investment Mistakes That Can Easily Be Avoided
text: How it works About us Data and AI Press and Blog How it works About us Data and AI Press and Blog EN ES Book a free investment session Prophero October 13, 2025 The Most Common Property Investment Mistakes That Can Easily Be Avoided Believe it or not, there are common investment mistakes that seasoned investors make everyday. Investing in property is a big decision, and even a small mistake can cost hundreds of thousands of dollars or slow your investment goals down by years. At PropHero, we care about investors and want to democratise property investment for everyone. That’s why we’re giving you the lessons we’ve learned over the years so you don’t make these same mistakes. Let’s get into it. Mistake #1. Using your emotions to guide you It sounds weird. We know. But buying property with y

title: The Most Common Property Investment Mistakes That Can Easily Be Avoided
text: t. Mistake #1. Using your emotions to guide you It sounds weird. We know. But buying property with your emotions is one of the biggest mistakes we see many investors make everyday. Maybe they want to invest or buy in an area close to home. Or maybe they feel the latest property they saw was made for them. All we can say is buying with your emotions makes it harder for you to assess a property in an objective way. Failing to assess the location of the property and whether it might be impacted by climate change, or the location and how the price might impact your ability to buy future properties are some of the biggest mistakes we see people make. And that leads us to the second mistake… Mistake #2: You do not have to invest in property where you live With services like PropHero, you do not

title: The Most Common Property Investment Mistakes That Can Easily Be Avoided
text: ke #2: You do not have to invest in property where you live With services like PropHero, you do not need to invest in property in your local area anymore. It may be tempting to go to open houses in your local area on the weekend to see if you can snag a deal, but it’s really not necessary. If you are focused on only purchasing in your local area, you are cutting yourself off from some the best deals you can find. There are properties in cheaper locations, but you won’t be able to access them if you only want to purchase in your existing state. Mistake #3: You’re not checking the property for its biggest risks If you are only concerned with price and want to snag a deal as quickly as possible, then you may not be giving yourself enough time to do your due diligence with the property. There

title: The Most Common Property Investment Mistakes That Can Easily Be Avoided
text: , then you may not be giving yourself enough time to do your due diligence with the property. There are over 200 variables our team checks with every property we purchase for clients, and if a property doesn’t make the cut, then we simply won’t purchase it. Doing your due diligence and checking the property for the basics including flood and fire risks, noise, infrastructure projects and macroeconomic conditions will make a massive difference to you succeeding in growing a profitable property portfolio Every year, we assess 18,000 properties, but we only purchase 500. This is because due diligence is such a massive factor for us. Conclusion: Avoiding these mistakes can be the difference between a profitable investment and a major headache. The key is to keep a cool head, analyze the data,

title: The Most Common Property Investment Mistakes That Can Easily Be Avoided
text: een a profitable investment and a major headache. The key is to keep a cool head, analyze the data, and rely on experts to help you make informed decisions. title: Capital Gains 101: A Simplified Guide for Smart Property Investing
text: How it works About us Data and AI Press and Blog How it works About us Data and AI Press and Blog EN ES Book a free investment session Prophero March 4, 2025 Capital Gains 101: A Simplified Guide for Smart Property Investing So you’re diving into the world of capital gains, and let me tell you, it’s more than just buying and selling assets. We’re talking about understanding the market game, planning your moves, and keeping an eye on those tax details. In this no-nonsense guide, we’re going to break down the jargon and give you practical strategies to rock your investment game. What Are Capital Gains? So, capital gains? A capital gain occurs when you sell an asset for more than what you initially paid to acquire that asset, reflecting the financial success of an investment. Types of Capital

title: Capital Gains 101: A Simplified Guide for Smart Property Investing
text: ally paid to acquire that asset, reflecting the financial success of an investment. Types of Capital Gains: Now, let’s chat about short-term and long-term gains. Short-term gains, applicable to assets held for one year or less, incur higher ordinary income tax rates. Conversely, long-term gains, arising from assets held for more than a year, often enjoy preferential tax rates. How Capital Gains Tax Works: Investors are obligated to pay taxes on capital gains, and this tax liability pertains to the tax year in which the investment is sold. The classification of capital gains tax varies depending on the duration of asset ownership. For investors holding an asset for a minimum of 1 year, long-term capital gains tax is applicable to the profits garnered upon the sale of the asset. Investors wi

title: Capital Gains 101: A Simplified Guide for Smart Property Investing
text: erm capital gains tax is applicable to the profits garnered upon the sale of the asset. Investors with an asset ownership period of less than 1 year are subject to short-term capital gains tax on the profits generated from the asset sale. These two types of gains incur different tax rates. Factors Influencing Capital Gains: Market Conditions: Market conditions significantly impact capital gains by influencing asset valuation, supply and demand, economic trends, and regulatory environments. Bullish markets may lead to appreciating asset values and favourable gains, while bearish markets can diminish gains or result in losses. Keeping your finger on the pulse of economic trends and market cycles is like having a superpower. Stay in the know, and you’ll make smarter investment moves. Tax Impl

title: Capital Gains 101: A Simplified Guide for Smart Property Investing
text: es is like having a superpower. Stay in the know, and you’ll make smarter investment moves. Tax Implications: The tax legislation favours individuals with long-term investment horizons (1 year or more), while it poses a disadvantage to those attempting to engage in frequent buying and selling of assets within a short timeframe. It’s crucial to have a clear understanding of the tax implications tied to your gains, aligning with your specific investment strategy. Implementing Capital Gains Strategies: Diversification and Risk Mitigation: Spread your investments like peanut butter on bread. A diversified portfolio serves as a risk mitigation tool, fostering a balanced approach to potential gains and losses. Holding Period and Tax-Efficient Investing: Increase the duration of your holding peri

title: Capital Gains 101: A Simplified Guide for Smart Property Investing
text: s and losses. Holding Period and Tax-Efficient Investing: Increase the duration of your holding period: retaining investments for over a year ensures more favorable tax treatments when the decision to sell is made. Regular Portfolio Review: Don’t let your investments gather dust. Regularly check in, adjust based on market trends, and balance your portfolio. Proactive portfolio management ensures alignment with your financial goals, fostering sustained growth. So, there you have it – navigating the realm of capital gains requires a balanced blend of practical knowledge and strategic insight. A well-informed and disciplined approach is your secret sauce to unlock the full potential of capital gains in your investment journey. Happy investing, my financial friend! Ready to embark on your inve

text: gains in your investment journey. Happy investing, my financial friend! Ready to embark on your investment journey with confidence? title: Are You Calculating Rental Yield Correctly?
text: How it works About us Data and AI Press and Blog How it works About us Data and AI Press and Blog EN ES Book a free investment session Prophero January 22, 2025 Are You Calculating Rental Yield Correctly? If you’re new to investing in property, there’s probably a lot of information flying at you about which area to invest in, which strategy to use, what buyers are the best and how to flip properties. Well. The list goes on. One thing that is really critical to get right at the beginning is rental yield, and it’s something we see our clients calculate incorrectly all the time. But don’t stress! We are here to show you how to calculate it based on two commonly used formulas and you’ll be surprised just how easy it is to calculate. But firstly. Let’s get on the same page about what “rental yi

title: Are You Calculating Rental Yield Correctly?
text: ised just how easy it is to calculate. But firstly. Let’s get on the same page about what “rental yield” really is. What is rental yield? Rental yield is a percentage that is used to express how profitable a property would be or currently is. It’s based on annual earnings, giving you a long term view on the feasibility of making an investment property work within the bounds of your budget and goals. How to Calculate Rental Yield Different Kinds of Rental Yield Some people get stuck calculating rental yield because there are two additional kinds which may impact your end result. Gross Rental Yield: This calculation considers only the rental income relative to the property’s total value or cost. It does not take into account other expenses associated with property ownership, such as property

title: Are You Calculating Rental Yield Correctly?
text: t. It does not take into account other expenses associated with property ownership, such as property management fees, maintenance costs, property taxes, and insurance. Net Rental Yield: This calculation considers the net income from the property after deducting all associated expenses. The formula is: Our Cashflow Calculator True to the PropHero way, we’ve done the hard work for you and have put together an easy to use spreadsheet that will calculate the rental yield for multiple properties in this cashflow calculator. Download it now to analyse the feasibility of investing in your next property. title: Property vs Shares: What’s the Difference & Which is Better for You?
text: How it works About us Data and AI Press and Blog How it works About us Data and AI Press and Blog EN ES Book a free investment session Prophero October 15, 2025 Property vs Shares: What’s the Difference & Which Is Better For You There are so many options when it comes to investing your money to grow wealth, and it can be really overwhelming and stressful choosing the right investment path for your unique situation. Let it be known though, that everyone’s personal situation is different and you’ll need to choose the right option based on your specific circumstances. When it comes to investing in property or shares there are distinct differences so we’ve created this post to help demystify the difference for you and help you choose the right path. The benefit of investing in property Investi

title: Property vs Shares: What’s the Difference & Which is Better for You?
text: difference for you and help you choose the right path. The benefit of investing in property Investing in property is a big decision. It can take time, there are costs to investing in property, but the reason millions of Australians choose to invest in property is because the overall return is higher, there is less risk compared to shares and you also get the experience of owning something tangible that could be passed on or sold later down the line. Unlike shares, investing in property gives you immediate access to cash flows. The average return for investing in the stock market can take up to 10 years. If you want to learn about the pitfalls of investing in property, you can download our 10 minute webinar here. This will give you tips and tricks on the areas and locations to avoid if you

title: Property vs Shares: What’s the Difference & Which is Better for You?
text: 0 minute webinar here. This will give you tips and tricks on the areas and locations to avoid if you’re concerned about investing in property. The benefit of investing in shares The stock market is known to be more liquid than investing in tangible properties. The higher the liquidity means the faster you’ll have access to cash. The stock market brings togethers millions of investors into one economy, which reduces the cost of every transaction significantly. Given the cost to entry of investing in stocks is very low, you can also spread your risk across multiple investments easily. The benefit of property over shares Though you may prefer the fast paced, almost betting nature of investing in stocks, the PropHero team firmly believes there are significant advantages of property investments

title: Property vs Shares: What’s the Difference & Which is Better for You?
text: n stocks, the PropHero team firmly believes there are significant advantages of property investments over shares. Check them out below: Leverage: You can borrow funds to amplify your return The bank will finance 80 or 80% of your investment which means if you invest wisely you can multiply the return on the money you invested by 5 or 10. This isn’t the case with the stock market. The bank is not going to lend you 80% of the money to invest in the stock market. Cash flows If you invest wisely you can get significant cash flows every month. And if you invest in the right areas, this can grow very quickly. There are not many other types of investment that can deliver cash flows that grow each month. The stock market is more volatile The stock markets are volatile. They go up and down all the

title: Property vs Shares: What’s the Difference & Which is Better for You?
text: onth. The stock market is more volatile The stock markets are volatile. They go up and down all the time. In property, despite the changes and booms, they are more stable over time and you won’t be at risk of losing your investment the same way you could with the stock market. In short, both types of investment have their advantages, but if you’re looking for greater stability, a steady income stream, and a tangible asset, real estate investment might be your best option. Want to analyze which of the two options is best for you? Book a free investment session with our experts and discover the strategy that best suits your financial goals.
